title: If you are considering bankruptcy Can you include the loan you took out of your 401k in the bankruptcy 7
question: I.m considering bankruptcy
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: A 401k loan is usually money you are borrowing against your own retirement account. A discharge in bankruptcy does not really do anything for you there. Most people that file a chapter 7 bankruptcy case usually just end up paying back the loan even after the bankruptcy is done, so they have a retirement account to live on later in life. You should consult with a bankruptcy lawyer so you can get professional assistance with your case.
Mr. Whitaker’s response is correct and answers the question you appear to be asking.

I'm going to assume, perhaps incorrectly, that you are wondering if you can include a 401(k) loan as a debt to be discharged in your bankruptcy. The answer is 'no'. It is a debt to yourself and, as such, is not really dischargeable. You are free to not pay it back, just as you are if NOT filing BK; but you will then owe income tax and early withdrawal penalties if you do ... whether you file BK or not.

Yes. Its required to list all debts and all income and expenses. And in fact the payment back on retirement loans helps on the means test too. But if you are asking, that implies you have NOT seen an experienced bankruptcy attorney and such failure could create huge problems. You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

Not only can you include a 401k loan, you must include it. When you sign your petition you do so under penalty of perjury. Sounds like you are considering BK w/o a lawyer. Big mistake. I recommend DJ Rausa in SD as a great starting place.
